instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.P2V7NAND_EN: What is P2V7NAND_EN? P2V7NAND_EN is a signal that enables the PP2V7_NAND power rail when it is high, which is a power rail necessary to turn on the SSD. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
Hey,

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with missing SSD. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> is 0,785V. Just wanted to measure around Piccolo Current Sense and - everything's missing. Just to be sure, there should be <CHIP>U5920</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R5920</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5925</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5920</CAPACITOR>? Also looks like <CHIP>U5910</CHIP> is missing...

Do i have bad schematics or is this real?

[ATTACH]60454[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
If you have direct connection over <RESISTOR>R5920</RESISTOR> (copper trace), then this circuitry area is not populated.

Be sure J9600 metal plate is in place and check left/right connections.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
Installed J9600 metal plate. <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> is 13.01V instead of 2.7

edit: looks like <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> should be 13V? 

Found <RESISTOR>R9415</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>P2V7NAND_DRVL_R</SIGNAL> and  <SIGNAL>P2V7NAND_DRVL</SIGNAL> at 0V 
.461 Diode
<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> is 5.107V instead of 2.7, same for <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_PVCC</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
Why do you make wrong assumptions so easy?
Do not confuse a power rail with associated signals.

Do you get voltage at L9300/20/30/40 and L9400?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
L9300 0.9V
L9320 0.85V
L9330 1.22V
L9340 1.81V
L9400 2.67V

From schematics <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> should be 2.7V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
Do you think to have big difference between 2.67 and 2.7???

As SSD power rails are good, check if is recognized in Disk Utility.
You can use Target Disk mode, or USB installer.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message: No, it was about <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_PVCC</SIGNAL> measured 5.107V and schematics say it must be 2.7.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
I tried to install OS X before i opened the Thread. I just tried it again with USB Installer and there's no SSD recognized. Questionmark Folder also still coming up.

[ATTACH]60456[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
"about PP2V7_NAND_[B][U]PVCC[/U][/B] measured 5.107V and schematics say it must be 2.7"
PLEASE, try to understand schematics, BEFORE making such WRONG assumption!!!

Be sure to select "Show All Devices" option in Disk Utility.
If still not detected, then read above:
"check left/right connections."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
Which left/right connections? Of J9600? 

Checked continuity for J9600, its okay. Tried a J9600 from another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, SSD still not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
Check SSD basic signals; <SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_LB_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>STORAGE_LB_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_LB_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SSD_PCIE_CLKREO_LB_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LPSR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL>.
If possible check 100MHz SSD clock with o-scope, or frequency meter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_LB_L</SIGNAL> 1.8V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>STORAGE_LB_EN</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.32V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PCIE_CLKREO_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.32V
<SIGNAL>LPSR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.32

Where to check clock? <SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_SSD_LB_N</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_SSD_LB_P</SIGNAL>?

at <RESISTOR>R9420</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>P2V7NAND_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PICCOLO_VEN1</SIGNAL> are 3.35V - is that correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NAND missing
threads.message:
Values look good.
Not sure about CLKREQ level, can you compare with working board?

" Where to check clock?"
Any CLK100M line...
